           <dd><em>&#x25cb;sv&#x0101;min</em> m. N. of a temple founded by Mahla&#x1e47;a <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; mahl&#x0101;&#x1e47;apura </dt>
           <dd><em>mahl&#x0101;&#x1e47;a-pura</em> n. N. of a town <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> (prob. w&#x1e5b;. for <em>mahla&#x1e47;a-</em> or <em>malha&#x1e47;a-p&#x25cb;</em>)</dd>

           <dt>m&#x0101; 1</dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x0101;&#x0341;</em> ind. (casting a following <em>ch</em> to be changed to <em>cch</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 6-1, 74) not, that not, lest, would that not <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a particle of prohibition or negation = Gk. ?, most commonly joined [804, 1] with the Subjunctive i.e. the augmentless form of a past tense (esp. of the aor., e.g. <em>m&#x0101;&#x0341; no vadh&#x012b;r indra</em>, do not slay us, O Indra <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x0101; bhai&#x1e63;&#x012b;&#x1e25;</em> or <em>m&#x0101; bhai&#x1e25;</em>, do not be afraid <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>tapovana-v&#x0101;sin&#x0101;m uparodho m&#x0101; bh&#x016b;t</em>, let there not be any disturbance of the inhabitants of the sacred grove <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;ak">&#x015a;ak.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; often also with <em>sma</em> e.g. <em>m&#x0101; sma gama&#x1e25;</em>, do not go <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhag">Bhag.</a>, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 3-3, 175 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 176 in the sense of, that not, lest' also <em>yath&#x0101; m&#x0101;</em> e.g. <em>yath&#x0101; m&#x0101; vo m&#x1e5b;tyu&#x1e25; pari-vyatk&#x0101; iti</em>, that death may not disturb you, Pra&#x015b;uUp </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or <em>m&#x0101;yath&#x0101;</em> e.g. <em>m&#x0101; bh&#x016b;t k&#x0101;l&#x00e2;tyayo yath&#x0101;</em>, lest there be any loss of time <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x0101; na</em> with aor. Subj. = Ind, without a negative, e.g. <em>m&#x0101; dvi&#x1e63;o na vadh&#x012b;r mama</em>, do slay my enemies <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;">Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> V&#x0101;m. v, 1, 9 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; rarely with the augmentless impf. with or without <em>sma</em> e.g. <em>ma&#x012b;7nam abhibh&#x0101;&#x1e63;ath&#x0101;&#x1e25;</em>, do not speak to him <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x0101; sma karot</em>, let him not do it <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 6-4, 74 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; exceptionally also with the Ind. of the aor., e.g., <em>m&#x0101;</em>, <em>k&#x0101;las tv&#x0101;m aty-ag&#x0101;t</em>, may not the season pass by thee <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> P&#x0101;&#x1e47;. 6-4, 75 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or with the Impv. (in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> only viii, 103, 6, <em>m&#x0101; no h&#x1e5b;&#x1e47;&#x012b;t&#x0101;m</em> [<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#SV">SV.</a> <em>h&#x1e5b;&#x1e47;&#x012b;t&#x0101;s</em> agn&#x00ed;H], may Agni not be angry with us </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; but very often in later language, e.g. <em>m&#x0101; kranda</em> do not cry <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>gaccha v&#x0101; m&#x0101; &#x0101;</em>, you can go or not go <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ripur ayam m&#x0101;j&#x0101;yat&#x0101;m</em>, may not this foe arise, &#x015a;alnti&#x015b; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also with <em>sma</em> e.g. <em>m&#x0101; sva ki&#x1e43; cid vaco vada</em> do not speak a word <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or with the Pot. (e.g. ma <em>yamam paseyam</em>, may l not Yama </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; esp. <em>m&#x0101;bhujema</em> in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or with the Prec. (only once in <em>m&#x0101; bh&#x016b;y&#x0101;t</em>, may it not be <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <em>B.</em> ii, 75, 45) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or sometimes with the fut. (= that not, lest, e.g. <em>m&#x0101;tv&#x0101;&#x1e43; &#x015b;apsye</em>, lest I curse thee <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a>, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> Vop. xxv, 27) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or with a participle (e.g. <em>m&#x0101;j&#x012b;vanyo du&#x1e25;khadagdho j&#x012b;vati</em>, he ought not to live who lives consumed by pain <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pa&#x00f1;cat">Pa&#x00f1;cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>gata&#x1e25; sa m&#x0101;</em>, he cannot have gone <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>ma&#x012b;7vampr&#x00e2;rthyam</em>, it must not be so requested <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sometimes for the simple negative <em>na</em> (e.g. <em>katham m&#x0101; bh&#x016b;t</em>, how may it not be <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x0101; gantum arhasi</em>, thou oughtest not to go, R </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x0101; bh&#x016b;d &#x0101;gata&#x1e25;</em>, can he not i.e. surely he must have arrived <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Amar">Amar.</a>) <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p804-2"></a>[Page 804, Column 2]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; occasionally without a verb (e. g. <em>m&#x0101; &#x015b;abda&#x1e25;</em> or <em>&#x015b;abdam</em>, do not make a noise <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x0101; n&#x0101;ma rak&#x1e63;i&#x1e47;a&#x1e25;</em>, may it not be the watchmen <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x1e5b;icch">M&#x1e5b;icch.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x0101; bhavantam anala&#x1e25; pavano v&#x0101;</em>, may not fire or wind harm thee <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;m">V&#x0101;m.</a> v, 1, 14 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; esp. = not so, e.g. <em>m&#x0101; pr&#x0101;t&#x1e5b;da</em>, not so, O Pr&#x1e6d;Pr&#x0101;t&#x1e5b;ida <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in this meaning also <em>m&#x0101; m&#x0101;</em>, <em>m&#x0101; m&#x00e2;ivam</em>, <em>m&#x0101; t&#x0101;vat</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in the Veda often with <em>u</em> (<em>m&#x00f4;&#x0341;</em>) = and not, nor (e.g. <em>m&#x0101;&#x0341; magh&#x00f3;na&#x1e25; p&#x00e1;ri khyatam m&#x00f4;&#x0341;asm&#x0101;&#x0341;kam &#x1e5b;&#x0301;&#x1e63;&#x1e47;&#x0101;m</em>, do not forget the rich lords nor us the poets <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> v, 65, 6 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; and then usually followed by <em>&#x1e63;&#x00fa;</em> = <em>s&#x00fa;</em> e.g. <em>m&#x00f4; &#x1e63;&#x00fa; &#x1e47;a&#x1e25; n&#x00ed;r&#x1e5b;tir vadh&#x012b;t</em>, let not N&#x00ed;r&#x1e5b;itir on any account destroy us, i, 38, 6) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <em>sma m&#x0101;</em> - <em>m&#x00f3; sma</em> = neither - nor (in a prohibitive sense)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; m&#x0101;kim </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kim</em> ind., g. <em>c&#x00e2;di</em> (cf. <em>na-kim</em> &amp;c.)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; m&#x0101;kis </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kis</em> (<em>m&#x0101;&#x0341;-</em>), ind. (only in prohibitive sentences with Subj.) may not or let not (= Lat. <em>ne</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ; may no one (= <em>ne-quis</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; m&#x0101;k&#x012b;m </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;k&#x012b;m</em> (<em>m&#x0101;&#x0341;-</em>), ind. may or let not (= <em>ne</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; m&#x0101;ciram </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;ciram</em> ind., 'not long', shortly, quickly <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> (generally after an Impv. or augmentless aor., and almost always at the end of a verse </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sometimes m. c. for <em>na-ciram</em>, q.v.)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; m&#x0101;vilambam </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;vilambam</em> (cf. Pa&#x00f1;cat.),</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; m&#x0101;vilambitam </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;vilambitam</em> (cf. BhP.), ind. without delay, shortly, quickly (in commands)</dd>

           <dt>m&#x0101; 2</dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x0101;</em> cl. 3. P. <em>m&#x00ed;rn&#x0101;ti</em> (accord. to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xxv, 6, &#x0100;. <em>mim&#x012b;te</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#SV">SV.</a> <em>mimeti</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Pot. <em>mim&#x012b;yat</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;&#x1e6d;h">K&#x0101;&#x1e6d;h.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pf, <em>mim&#x0101;ya</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>&#x00e1;m&#x012b;met</em> Subj. <em>m&#x012b;mayat</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>m&#x0101;&#x0341;tava&#x00ed;</em>), to sound, bellow, roar, bleat (esp. said of cows, calves, goats &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a>: Intens., only pr. p. <em>m&#x00e9;myat</em>, bleating (as a goat) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 162, 2</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; m&#x0101;yu 1</dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x0101;yu</em> m. (for 2. p. 811, col. 2) bleating, bellowing, lowing, roaring <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;rS">&#x015a;rS.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; 'the bleater or bellower', N. of a partic. animal or of a Kim-purusha <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; m&#x0101;y&#x016b;ka </dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x0101;y&#x016b;ka</em> mfn. bellowing, roaring <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>m&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x0101;</em> cl. 2. P. (cf. Dh&#x0101;tup. xxiv, 54) <em>m&#x0101;ti</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cl. 3. &#x0100;. (xxv, 6) <em>m&#x00ed;m&#x012b;te</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cl. 4. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#A">A.</a> (xxvi, 33) <em>m&#x0101;yate</em> (Ved. and ep. also <em>mim&#x0101;ti</em> Pot. <em>mim&#x012b;y&#x0101;t</em> Impv., <em>mim&#x012b;hi</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Pot. <em>mimet</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>mama&#x00fa;</em>, <em>mame</em>, <em>mamir&#x00e9;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>&#x00e1;in&#x0101;si</em> Subj. <em>mas&#x0101;tai</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>am&#x0101;s&#x012b;t</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Prec. <em>m&#x0101;s&#x012b;&#x1e63;&#x1e6d;a</em>, <em>mey&#x0101;t</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>m&#x0101;t&#x0101;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x0101;syati</em>, <em>m&#x0101;syate</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>m&#x00e9;</em> <em>-ma&#x00ed;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x0101;tum</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ind. p. <em>mitv&#x0101;&#x0341;</em>, <em>-m&#x0101;&#x0341;ya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c.), to measure, mete out, mark off <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to measure across = traverse <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to measure (by any standard), compare with (instr.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kum">Kum.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>m&#x0101;ti</em>) to correspond in measure (either with gen., 'to be large or long enough for' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or with loc., to find room or be contained in' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Inscr">Inscr.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or with <em>na</em> and instr., 'to be beside one's self with <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vcar">Vcar.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to measure out, apportion, grant <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to help any one (acc.) to anything (dat.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a>, i, 120, 9 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to prepare, arrange, fashion, form, build, make <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to show, display, exhibit (<em>amim&#x012b;ta</em>, 'he displayed or developed himself', iii, 29, 11) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in phil.) to infer, conclude </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to pray (<em>y&#x0101;c&#x00f1;&#x0101;-karma&#x1e47;i</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naigh">Naigh.</a> iii, 59: Pass. <em>m&#x012b;y&#x00e1;te</em> (aor. <em>am&#x0101;yi</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to be measured &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c.: Caus, <em>m&#x0101;payati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> (aor. <em>am&#x012b;mapat</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 7-4, 93 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a> 2 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a>), to cause to be measured or built, measure, build, erect <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Up">Up.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#G&#x1e5b;S">G&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c.: Desid. <em>mitsati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 7-4, 54 ; 58 (cf. <em>nir-&#x221a;m&#x0101;</em>): Intens. <em>mem&#x012b;yate</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 6-4, 66.            <dt>&#x226b; m&#x0101;tulu&#x1e45;gaka </dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x0101;tulu&#x1e45;gaka</em> m. = <em>m&#x0101;tulunga</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>ik&#x0101;</em>), f. the wild citron tree <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a></dd>

           <dt>m&#x0101;t&#x1e5b; 2</dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x0101;t&#x1e5b;&#x0301;</em> f. (derivation from &#x221a;3. <em>m&#x0101;</em> very doubtful </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; for 1. <em>m&#x0101;&#x0341;t&#x1e5b;</em>, p. 804, col. 2) a mother, any mother (applicable to animals) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (sometimes ifc., e.g. <em>kunt&#x012b;-m&#x25cb;</em>, having Kunt&#x012b; for a mother) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; du. father and mother, parents <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> iii, 3, 33 ; vii, 2, 5 (also', <em>m&#x0101;t&#x00e1;r&#x0101;-pit&#x00e1;r&#x0101;</em>, iv, 6, 7, and <em>pit&#x00e1;r&#x0101;-m&#x0101;t&#x00e1;r&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 6-3, 33 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf. <em>m&#x0101;tarapitarau</em>, col. 2) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the earth (du. heaven and earth) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with or scil. <em>lokasya</em>), a cow <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (du. and pl.) the two pieces of wood used in kindling fire <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> (cf. <em>dvi-m&#x25cb;</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (pl.) the waters <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> (cf. <em>saptam&#x25cb;</em> and <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Naigh">Naigh.</a> i, 13) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (pl.) the divine mothers or personified energies of the principal deities (sometimes reckoned as 7 in number, viz. Br&#x0101;hm&#x012b; or Brahm&#x0101;&#x1e47;i, M&#x0101;he&#x015b;var&#x012b;, Kaum&#x0101;r&#x012b;, Vaish&#x1e47;avii, V&#x0101;r&#x0101;h&#x012b;, Indr&#x0101;&#x1e47;! or Aindr&#x012b; or Mihendr&#x012b;, C&#x0101;mu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;&#x0101; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sometimes 8, viz. Br&#x0101;hmi, M&#x0101;he&#x015b;var&#x012b;, Kaum&#x0101;ri, Vaish&#x1e47;avii, V&#x0101;r&#x0101;h&#x012b;, Raudr&#x012b;, Carma-mu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;&#x0101;, K&#x0101;la-sa&#x1e43;pkarshi&#x1e47;&#x012b; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sometimes 9, viz. Brahm&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x012b;, Vaish&#x1e47;avii, Raudr&#x012b;, V&#x0101;r&#x0101;h&#x012b;, N&#x0101;rasi&#x1e43;hik&#x0101;, Kaum&#x0101;ri, M&#x0101;hendr&#x012b;, C&#x0101;mu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;&#x0101;, Ca&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ik&#x0101; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; sometimes 16, viz. Gaur&#x012b;, Padm&#x0101;, &#x015a;ac&#x012b;, Medh&#x0101;, S&#x0101;vitr&#x012b;, Vijay&#x0101;, Jay&#x0101;, Deva-sen&#x0101;, Sva-dh&#x0101;, Sv&#x0101;h&#x0101;, &#x015a;&#x0101;nti, Push&#x1e6d;i, Dh&#x1e5b;iti, Tush&#x1e6d;i, &#x0100;tma-devat&#x0101; and Kula-devat&#x0101; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; they are closely connected with the worship of &#x015a;iva and are described as attending on his son Skanda or K&#x0101;rttikeya, to whom at first only 7 M&#x0101;t&#x1e5b;is were assigned, but later an innumerable number </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also the 13 wives of Ka&#x015b;yapa are called, <em>lok&#x0101;n&#x0101;m m&#x0101;tara&#x1e25;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hcat">Hcat.</a> (cf. RTL. 222 &amp;c.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (pl.) the 8 classes of female ancestors (viz. mothers, grandmothers, great-grandmothers, paternal and maternal aunts &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sa&#x1e43;sk&#x0101;rak">Sa&#x1e43;sk&#x0101;rak.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; but the word 'mother' is also applied to other female relatives and in familiar speech to elderly women generally) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of Lakshm&#x012b; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhart&#x1e5b;">Bhart&#x1e5b;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of Durg&#x0101; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of D&#x0101;ksh&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;i in certain places <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; accord. to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> also = a colocynth </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Salvinia Cucullata, Nardostachys Jatamansi, Sphaerantus Indicus </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; air, space </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the lower mill-stone </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; = <em>vibh&#x016b;ti</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-revat&#x012b;</em>. [Cf. Gk., ?, ? ; Lat. <em>mater</em> ; [807, 1] Lith. <em>mote</em> ; Slav. <em>mati</em> ; Germ. <em>muotar</em>, <em>&#x1e43;utter</em> ; Eng. <em>mother</em>.]</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (in astron.) N. of the tenth house <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> (cf. W. also a blockhead <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p809-2"></a>[Page 809, Column 2]</font> </dd>

           <dt>m&#x0101;nasa </dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x0101;nas&#x00e1;</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;</em>, once <em>&#x0101;</em>)n. (fr. <em>m&#x00e1;nas</em>) belonging to the mind or spirit, mental, spiritual (opp. to <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;rir&#x0101;</em>, corporeal) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VS">VS.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; expressed only in the mind, performed in thought, i.e. silent, tacit (as a hymn or prayer) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;rS">&#x015a;rS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; conceived or present in the mind, conceivable, imaginable <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; relating to or dwelling on the lake M&#x0101;nasa ( n. below) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. a form of Vish&#x1e47;u <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a serpent-demon <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a son of Vapush-mat <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x0101;rkP">M&#x0101;rkP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pl. a partic. class of deceased ancestors (regarded as sons of Vasish&#x1e6d;ha) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a class of ascetics <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;matUp">R&#x0101;matUp.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the Vai&#x015b;yas in &#x015a;kadviipa <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of the worlds of the Soma-pa <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. (with <em>p&#x016b;ja</em>) mental or spiritual devotion (opp. to <em>m&#x016b;rti-p&#x25cb;</em>, adoration of images) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 524 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a Ki&#x1e43;-nar&#x012b; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ra&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;">K&#x0101;ra&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a Vidy&#x0101;-devii <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. (ifc. f. <em>&#x0101;</em>) the mental powers, mind, spirit, heart, soul (= <em>manas</em> g. <em>praj&#x00f1;&#x00e2;di</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ka&#x1e6d;hUp">Ka&#x1e6d;hUp.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in law) tacit or implied consent <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a kind of salt <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r">K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the 25th mansion from that under which one is born <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarYogay">VarYogay.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with or scil' <em>saras</em>, or <em>t&#x012b;rtha</em>) N. of a sacred like and place of pilgrimage on mount Kail&#x0101;sa (the native place of the wild geese, which migrate to it every year at the breeding season) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of wk. on &#x015a;ilpa or art</dd>

           <dd><em>m&#x0101;y&#x0101;&#x0341;</em> f. art, wisdom, extraordinary or supernatural power (only in the earlier language) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; illusion, unreality, deception, fraud, trick, sorcery, witchcraft magic <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an unreal or illusory image, phantom, apparition <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> (esp. ibc= false, unreal, illusory </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#comp">comp.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; duplicity (with Buddhists one of the 24 minor evil passions) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dharmas">Dharmas.</a> 69 (in phil.)            <dd>&#x2022; (with &#x015a;aivas) one of the 4 P&#x0101;&#x015b;as or snares which entangle the soul <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sarvad">Sarvad.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; Illusion personified (sometimes identified with Durg&#x0101;, sometimes regarded as a daughter of An&#x1e5b;ita and Nir&#x1e5b;iti or Nik&#x1e5b;iti and mother of M&#x1e5b;ityu, or as a daughter of Adharma) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; compassion, sympathy <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Convolvulus Turpethum <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>

           <dd><em>m&#x0101;yya</em> <em>puru-m&#x0101;&#x0341;yya</em>. <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p811-3"></a>[Page 811, Column 3]</font>
</dd>

           <dt>m&#x0101;ra </dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x0101;ra</em> mfn. (&#x221a;<em>m&#x1e5b;</em>) killing, destroying </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. death, pestilence <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a>Pari&#x015b; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; slaying, killing <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> (cf. <em>pa&#x015b;u-m&#x25cb;</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an obstacle, hindrance <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;s">V&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the passion of love, god of love <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with Buddhists) the Destroyer, Evil One (who tempts men to indulge their passions and is the great enemy of the Buddha and his religion </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; four M&#x0101;ras are enumerated in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dharmas">Dharmas.</a> 80, viz. <em>skandha-</em>, <em>kle&#x015b;a-</em>, <em>devaputra-</em>, and <em>m&#x1e5b;tyu-m&#x25cb;</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; but the later Buddhist theory of races of gods led to the figment of millions of M&#x0101;ras ruled over by a chief M&#x0101;ra) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MWB">MWB.</a> 208 &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the thorn-apple <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. killing, slaughter <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Prasannar">Prasannar.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pestilence (also personified as the goddess of death and identified with Durg&#x0101;) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a>Pari&#x015b;. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; m&#x0101;rga </dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x0101;rga</em> m. (in most meanings fr. <em>m&#x1e5b;ga</em>, of which it is also the V&#x1e5b;iddhi form in comp.) seeking, search, tracing out, hunting <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (exceptionally also n </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ifc. f. <em>&#x0101;</em>) the track of a wild animal, any track, road, path, way to (loc. or comp.) or through (comp.), course (also of the wind and the stars) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c. (<em>m&#x0101;rga&#x1e43;-&#x221a;d&#x0101;</em> or <em>yam</em>, with gen. of pers., to give up the way to, allow to pass </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x0101;ge&#x1e47;a</em> ifc. = by way of i.e. through, across or along </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with &#x221a;<em>y&#x0101;</em>, to go the way of i.e. suffer the same fate as </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x0101;rgais</em> ifc., through </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x0101;rg&#x0101;ya</em>, with gen., in order to make way for any one </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>pra-&#x221a;cal</em>, to set out on one's way </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>nijam&#x0101;rga&#x1e43;-&#x221a;gam</em>, to go one's way) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a walk, journey <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; a scar, mark (left by a wound &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Ragh">Ragh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in medic.) a way, passage, channel (in any part of the body, esp. the intestinal canal, anus) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a way, expedient, means <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;m">K&#x0101;m.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> (<em>m&#x0101;rge&#x1e47;a</em>, by means of. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a way, manner method, custom, usage <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Up">Up.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;">Y&#x0101;j&#x00f1;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; m&#x0101;sa </dt>

           <dd>&#x2022; a month or the 12th part of the Hind&#x016b; year (there are 4 kinds of months, viz. the solar, <em>saura</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the natural, <em>s&#x0101;vana</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the stellar, <em>n&#x0101;k&#x1e63;atra</em>, and the lunar, <em>c&#x00e2;ndra</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the latter, which is the most usual and consists of 30 Tithis, being itself of two kinds as reckoned from the new or full moon, <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> IW. 179 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; for the names of the months <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> 173, n. 3) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (<em>m&#x0101;sam</em>, for a month </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x0101;sam ekam</em>, for one month </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x0101;se</em>, in a month = after the lapse of a m&#x1e6d;month) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a symbolical N. for the number 'twelve' <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x016b;ryas">S&#x016b;ryas.</a></dd>

           <dt>mi 1</dt>
           <dd><em>mi</em> (cf. &#x221a;3. <em>m&#x0101;</em> and <em>m&#x012b;</em>), c, l. 5. P.&#x0100;. (<a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a> xxvii, 4) <em>min&#x00f3;ti</em>, <em>minute</em> (pf. P. <em>mim&#x0101;ya</em>, <em>mimy&#x00fa;&#x1e25;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a>, <em>mamau</em>, Gr, </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; &#x0100;. <em>mimye</em> Gr. aor. <em>am&#x0101;s&#x012b;t</em>, <em>&#x25cb;sta</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Prec. <em>m&#x012b;y&#x0101;t</em>, <em>m&#x0101;r&#x012b;rh&#x1e6d;a</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut. <em>m&#x0101;t&#x0101;</em>, <em>m&#x0101;syati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; p. <em>me&#x1e63;yat</em> [?] <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AitBr">AitBr.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ind, p. <em>-mitya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a>, <em>-m&#x0101;ya</em> Gr.), to fix or fasten in the earth, set up, found, build, construct <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;rS">&#x015a;rS.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to mete out, measure <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to judge, observe, perceive, know <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#M&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;Up">M&#x0101;&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;Up.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cast, throw, scatter <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dh&#x0101;tup">Dh&#x0101;tup.</a>: Pass. <em>m&#x012b;y&#x00e1;te</em> (aor. <em>am&#x0101;yi</em> Gr.), to be fixed &amp;c. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a>, : Caus. <em>m&#x0101;payati</em> (aor. <em>am&#x012b;mapat</em>), Gr.: Desid. <em>mitsati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a>: Intens. <em>mem&#x012b;yate</em>, <em>memay&#x012b;te</em>, <em>memeti</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; mit </dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x00ed;t</em> f. anything set up or erected, a post, pillar <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> (cf. <em>garta-</em>., <em>upa-</em>, <em>prati-m&#x25cb;</em>)</dd>

           <dt>mitra 1</dt>
           <dd><em>mitr&#x00e1;</em> m. (orig. <em>mit-tra</em>, fr. &#x221a;<em>mith</em> or <em>mid</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; cf, <em>medin</em>) a friend, companion, associate <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> (in later language mostly n.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of an &#x0100;ditya (generally invoked together with Varu&#x1e47;a, cf. <em>mitr&#x0101;-v&#x25cb;</em>, and often associated with Aryaman, q.v </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Mitra is extolled alone in <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> iii, 59, and there described as calling men to activity, sustaining earth and sky and beholding all creatures with unwinking eye </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; in later times he is considered as the deity of the constellation Anur&#x0101;dh&#x0101;, and father of Utsarga) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the sun <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c. (cf. comp.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a Marut <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a son of Vasish&#x1e6d;ha and various other men <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of the third Muh&#x016b;rta <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; du. = <em>mitr&#x00e1;-varu&#x1e47;a</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. N. of an Apsaras <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> (B. <em>citr&#x0101;</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of the mother of Maitreya and Maitrey&#x012b; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;a&#x1e43;k">&#x015a;a&#x1e43;k.</a> on <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ChUp">ChUp.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of the mother of &#x015a;atru-ghna (= <em>su-mitr&#x0101;</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> (cf. W. <em>&#x012b;</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. friendship <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a friend, companion (cf. m. above) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> &amp;c, &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with <em>aurasa</em>) a friend connected by blood-relationship <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hit">Hit.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an ally (a prince whose territory adjoins that of an immediate neighbour who is called <em>ari</em>, enemy. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> vii, 158 &amp;c., in this meaning also applied to planets <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a companion to = resemblance of (gen </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ifc. = resembling, like) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#B&#x0101;lar">B&#x0101;lar.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Vcar">Vcar.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the god Mitra (enumerated among the 10 fires) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a partic. mode of fighting <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> (v. l. for <em>bhinna</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; mitrakara&#x1e47;a </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kara&#x1e47;a</em> the making of friends, m&#x1e6d;making one's self friends <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-3, 25 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a> 1 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a></dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; but <em>mitra k&#x1e5b;yeva</em>, instead of being understood as <em>&#x25cb;tyeva</em>, could also be resolved into the words <em>&#x25cb;tya</em> ind 'making a friend', and <em>iva</em>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; mithy&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>mithy&#x0101;&#x0341;</em> ind. (contracted from <em>mith&#x016b;y&#x0101;&#x0341;</em>) invertedly, contrarily, incorrectly, wrongly, improperly <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (with Caus, of &#x221a;<em>k&#x1e5b;</em>, to pronounce a word wrongly 'once' <em>P.</em> or 'repeatedly' <em>&#x0101;a.</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-3, 71 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>pra-&#x221a;car</em>, to act wrongly <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> ix, 284 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with <em>pra-&#x221a;v&#x1e5b;t</em>, to behave improperly <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> iii, 2414) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; falsely, deceitfully, untruly <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c. (often with &#x221a;<em>br&#x016b;</em>, <em>vac</em> or <em>vad</em>, to speak falsely, utter a lie </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with &#x221a;<em>k&#x1e5b;</em>, to deny <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to break one's word, with <em>na-&#x221a;k&#x1e5b;</em>, to keep it) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with &#x221a;<em>bh&#x016b;</em>, to turn out or prove false <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; not in reality, only apparently <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Madhus">Madhus.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to no purpose, fruitlessly, in vain <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MaitrUp">MaitrUp.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c. (ibc. often = false, untrue, sham </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Mithy&#x0101; is personified as the wife of A-dharma <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#KalkiP">KalkiP.</a>)</dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; mithila </dt>
           <dd><em>mithila</em> m. N. of a king (the founder of Mithil&#x0101;) = <em>mithi</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#BhP">BhP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pl. N. of a people (prob. the inhabitants of Mithil&#x0101;) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f.            <dd>&#x2022; (<em>u&#x1e63;&#x012b;</em>), f. N. of Devii (the wife of &#x012a;&#x015b;&#x0101;na) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x0100;pG&#x1e5b;">&#x0100;pG&#x1e5b;.</a></dd>

           <dd><em>mukh&#x012b;ya</em> mfn. (ifc.) being at the top or head, being foremost ( <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;l&#x0101;-</em>, <em>savana-m&#x25cb;</em> &amp;c.)</dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; m. the lopped trunk or stem of a tree, pollard <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a shaver, barber <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>ik&#x0101;</em>), f. a species of plant <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. the head <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the chapters into which the Mu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;akopanishad is divided</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; mu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;akopani&#x1e63;ad </dt>
           <dd><em>mu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;ak&#x00f4;pani&#x1e63;ad</em> f. N. of a well-known Upanishad of the Atharva-veda (called also &#x0100;tharva&#x1e47;&#x00f4;panishad and said to take its former name from the word <em>mu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;a</em>, because every one who comprehends its sacred doctrine is 'shorn', i.e. liberated from all error, a similar idea being probably involved in the name of the Kshurikopanishad or 'Razor Upanishad' </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#cf">cf.</a> IW. 35, 39 &amp;c.) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x25cb;&#x1e63;at-kha&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;&#x00e2;rtha</em>, m </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x25cb;&#x1e63;ad-&#x0101;loka</em> m. <em>&#x25cb;&#x1e63;add&#x012b;pik&#x0101;</em> f. and <em>&#x25cb;&#x1e63;ad-bh&#x0101;&#x1e63;ya</em> n. N. of Comms. on the <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;Up">Mu&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;Up.</a></dd>

           <dt>mudr&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>mudr&#x0101;</em> f. (fr. <em>mudra</em>, above) a seal or any instrument used for sealing or stamping, a seal-ring, signet-ring (cf. <em>a&#x1e45;guli-m&#x25cb;</em>), any ring <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; a stamped coin, piece of money, rupee, cash, medal <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an image, sign, badge, token (esp. a token or mark of divine attributes impressed upon the body) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; shutting, closing (as of the eyes or lips, gen. or comp.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a lock, stopper, bung <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Amar">Amar.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhpr">Bhpr.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a mystery <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of partic. positions or intertwinings of the fingers (24 in number, commonly practised in religious worship, and supposed to possess an occult meaning and magical efficacy <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Da&#x015b;">Da&#x015b;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sarvad">Sarvad.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ra&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;">K&#x0101;ra&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RTL">RTL.</a> 204 ; 406) </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; (in rhet.) the natural expression of things by words, calling things by their right names <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kuval">Kuval.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; pf. <em>mumoha</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> &amp;c. <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p825-1"></a>[Page 825, Column 1]</font> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; aor, <em>am&#x016b;muhat</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Pass, <em>mohyate</em>), to stupefy, bewilder, confound, perplex, cause to err or fail <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (&#x0100;., with <em>adhv&#x0101;nam</em>) to cause to go the wrong way <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a>: Desid. <em>mumohi&#x1e63;ati</em>, <em>mumuhi&#x1e63;ati</em>, <em>mumuk&#x1e63;ati</em> Gr.: Intens. <em>momuhyate</em> (cf.            <dd><em>m&#x016b;rta</em> <em>m&#x016b;rti</em>, p. 824, col. 1</dd>

           <dt>m&#x016b;rts&#x0101; </dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x016b;rts&#x0101;</em> f. = <em>m&#x016b;sch&#x0101;</em>, fainting away <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Gal">Gal.</a></dd>

           <dt>m&#x016b;rdhan </dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x016b;rdh&#x00e1;n</em> m. (cf. U&#x1e47;. i, 158) the forehead, head in general, skull, (fig.) the highest or first part of anything, top, point, summit, front (of battle), commencement, beginning, first, chief (applied to persons) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c, &amp;c, (<em>m&#x016b;rdhni</em> with &#x221a;<em>v&#x1e5b;t</em> &amp;c., to be above everything, prevail </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; with &#x221a;<em>dh&#x1e5b;</em>, or <em>&#x0101;-&#x221a;d&#x0101;</em> = <em>m&#x016b;rdhn&#x0101;</em> &#x221a;1. <em>k&#x1e5b;</em>, to place on the head, hold in high honour) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the base (in geom </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; opp. to <em>agra</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; perhaps w&#x1e5b;. for <em>budhna</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Col">Col.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in gram.) the roof or top of the palate (as one of the 8 Sthanas or places of utterance) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-1, 9 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with Buddhists) 'the summit', N. of a state of spiritual exaltation <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Divy&#x00e2;v">Divy&#x00e2;v.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; m&#x016b;rdhanvat </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;v&#x00e1;t</em> mfn. containing the word <em>m&#x016b;rdhan</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#TS">TS.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; m. N. of a Gandharva <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#T&#x0100;r">T&#x0100;r.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; a radish or the &#x221a;of various other plants (esp. of Arum Campanulatum, of long pepper, and of Costus Speciosus or Arabicus) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the edge (of the horizon) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Megh">Megh.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; basis, foundation, cause, origin, commencement, beginning (<em>m&#x016b;l&#x0101;d &#x0101;rabhya</em> or <em>&#x0101;</em> <em>m&#x016b;l&#x0101;t</em>, from the beg&#x1e6d;beginning </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x016b;l&#x0101;t</em>, from the bottom, thoroughly </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x016b;la&#x1e43;</em> <em>kramata&#x015b; ca</em>, right through from beginning <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Divy&#x00e2;v">Divy&#x00e2;v.</a>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c.            <dd>&#x2022; an original text (as opp. to the commentary or gloss) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a king's original or proper territory <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> vii, 184 </dd>

           <dd><em>m&#x1e5b;ty&#x00fa;</em> m. (very rarely f.) death, dying <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c, &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (deaths of different kinds are enumerated, 100 from disease or accident and one natural from old age </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ifc. = 'disease caused by or through') </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Death personified, the god of disease (sometimes identified with Yama or with Vish&#x1e47;u </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; or said to be a son of Adharma by Nir&#x1e5b;iti or of Brahm&#x0101; or of Kali or of M&#x0101;y&#x0101; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; he has also the patronymics Pr&#x0101;dhva&#x1e43;sana and S&#x0101;mpar&#x0101;ya&#x1e47;a, and is sometimes reckoned among the 11 Rudras, and sometimes regarded as Vy&#x0101;sa in the 6th Dv&#x0101;para or as a teacher &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;Br">&#x015a;Br.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the god of love <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> <font color="#FF0000" font size=-2><a name="p828-1"></a>[Page 828, Column 1]</font> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a partic. Ek&#x00e2;ha <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r">&#x015a;&#x0101;&#x1e45;kh&#x015a;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of the 8th astrol. house <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of the 17th astrol. Yoga <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Col">Col.</a> (<em>m&#x1e5b;tyor harah</em> and <em>mrityor vikar&#x1e47;a-bh&#x0101;se</em>, N. of S&#x0101;mans)</dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; m&#x1e5b;tyukany&#x0101; </dt>

           <dt>m&#x1e5b;g </dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x1e5b;g</em> (rather Nom. fr. <em>m&#x1e5b;ga</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#&#x221a;">&#x221a;.</a><em>m&#x0101;rg</em>, <em>m&#x1e5b;j</em>), cl. 4. P., 10 &#x0100;. (cf. Dh&#x0101;tup. xxvi, 137 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; xxxv, 46) <em>m&#x1e5b;gyati</em>, <em>m&#x1e5b;g&#x00e1;yate</em> (m. c. also P. <em>&#x25cb;ti</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; pr. p. <em>m&#x1e5b;gay&#x0101;&#x1e47;a</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a>), to chase, hunt, pursue <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to seek, search for or through, investigate, examine <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to visit, frequent <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to seek or strive after, aim at, endeavour to obtain (acc.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to desire or request or ask anything (acc.) from (abl., <em>-tas</em>, gen. with or without <em>sak&#x0101;&#x015b;&#x0101;t</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; m&#x1e5b;ga </dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x1e5b;g&#x00e1;</em> m. (prob. 'ranger', 'rover') a forest animal or wild beast, game of any kind, (esp.) a deer, fawn, gazelle, antelope, stag, musk-deer <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the deer or antelope in the moon (i.e. the spots on the disk supposed to resemble those of an antelope as well as a hare) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the disk or ant&#x1e6d;antelope in the sky (either the Nakshatra M&#x1e5b;iga-&#x015b;iras or the sign of the zodiac Capricorn </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; also in general the 10th arc of 30 degrees in a circle) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#S&#x016b;ryas">S&#x016b;ryas.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; an elephant with partic. marks (accord. to <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> 'one the secondary marks of whose body are small') <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Var">Var.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a large soaring bird <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> i, 182, 7 &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of a demon or V&#x1e5b;itra in the form of a deer slain by Indra <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> i, 80, 7 &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a celestial being (occupying a partic. place in an astrol. house divided into 81 compartments) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hcat">Hcat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a partic. class of men whose conduct in coitus resembles that of the roebuck <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of the district in &#x015a;aka-dviipa inhabited principally by Br&#x0101;hdvipa themselves <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> (v&#x1e37;. <em>maga</em>) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a horse of the Moou <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; musk (= <em>m&#x1e5b;ga-n&#x0101;bhi</em> or <em>-mada</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a partic. Aja-p&#x0101;ia sacrifice <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; search, seeking, asking, requesting <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x0101;</em>), f. = <em>m&#x1e5b;ga-viith&#x012b;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (<em>&#x012b;</em>), f. a female deer or antelope, doe <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the mythical progenitress of antelopes <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pur">Pur.</a> </dd>

           <dt>m&#x1e5b;d 1</dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x1e5b;d</em> (cf. &#x221a;<em>mrad</em> and <em>m&#x1e5b;&#x1e0d;</em>), cl. 9. P. <em>m&#x1e5b;dn&#x0101;ti</em> (cl. s. P. &#x0100;. <em>m&#x00e1;rdati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; pt P. <em>mamarda</em>, 3. pl. <em>mam&#x1e5b;duh</em>. or <em>mamardu&#x1e25;</em> &#x0100;. <em>mam&#x1e5b;de</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor, <em>amarad&#x012b;t</em> Gr </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fut, <em>mardi&#x1e63;yati</em>, <em>&#x25cb;te</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; inf. <em>marditum</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>&#x25cb;tos</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-mrad&#x00e9;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ind, p, <em>mriditv&#x0101;</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 1-2, 7 </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>m&#x1e5b;&#x0301;dya</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Br">Br.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-mardam</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a>), to press, squeeze, crush, pound, smash, trample down, tread upon, destroy, waste, ravage, kill, slay <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to rub, stroke, wipe (e.g. the forehead) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#ib">ib.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to rub into, mingle with (instr.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Su&#x015b;r">Su&#x015b;r.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to rub against, touch, pass through (a constellation) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to overcome, surpass <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;">Bha&#x1e6d;&#x1e6d;.</a>: Caus. <em>mardayati</em> (m. c. also <em>&#x25cb;te</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; aor. <em>am&#x012b;mridat</em> or <em>amamardat</em>), to press or squeeze hard, crush, break, trample down, oppress, torment, plague, destroy, kill <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to rub <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Kath&#x0101;s">Kath&#x0101;s.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; to cause to be trampled down <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r">K&#x0101;ty&#x015a;r.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Sch">Sch.</a>: Desid. <em>mimardi&#x1e63;ati</em>, to desire to crush or pound <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> Intens. <em>marmartti</em> (only Impv. <em>&#x25cb;ttu</em> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#RV">RV.</a> ii, 23, 6), to crush, grind down, destroy </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; to put up with anything from (gen.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R">R.</a> </dd>

           <dd><em>&#x25cb;"&#x1e63;rtha</em> (<em>m&#x1e5b;&#x1e63;&#x00e2;r&#x25cb;</em>), mfn. having a false sense meaning, untrue, absurd, Praca&#x1e47;&#x1e0d; </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>-ka</em> mfn. id. <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; n. an impassibility, absurdity (e, g. horn on a rabbit &amp;c.) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#W">W.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; m&#x1e5b;&#x1e63;&#x0101;vacana </dt>

           <dd><em>mera&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;u</em> (?) = <em>mel&#x00e2;ndhu</em>, an inkstand <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;ra&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;">K&#x0101;ra&#x1e47;&#x1e0d;.</a></dd>

           <dt>meru </dt>
           <dd><em>meru</em> m. (cf. U&#x1e47;. iv, 101) N. of a fabulous mountain (regarded as the Olympus of Hind&#x016b; mythology and said to form the central point of Jambu-dviipa </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; all the planets revolve round it and it is compared to the cup or seed-vessel of a lotus, the leaves of which are formed by the different Dvipas, q.v </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the river Ganges falls from heaven on its summit, and flows thence to the surrounding worlds in four streams </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the regents of the four quarters of the compass occupy the corresponding faces of the mountain, the whole of which consists of gold and gems </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; its summit is the residence of Brahm&#x0101;, and a place of meeting for the gods, Rishis, Gandharvas &amp;c., when not regarded as a fabulous mountain, it appears to mean the highland of Tartary north of the Him&#x00e2;laya) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a partic. kind of temple <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VarB&#x1e5b;S">VarB&#x1e5b;S.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the central or most prominent bead in a rosary <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; the most prominent finger-joint in partic. positions of the fingers <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the palace of G&#x0101;ndh&#x0101;ri (one of the wives of K&#x1e5b;ish&#x1e47;a) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Hariv">Hariv.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of a Cakra-vartin <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with <em>&#x015b;&#x0101;strin</em>) of a modern teacher <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; of another man <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#R&#x0101;jat">R&#x0101;jat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; f. N. of the wife of N&#x0101;bhi and mother of &#x1e5a;ishabha <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a> (cf. <em>-devii</em>)</dd>

           <dt>maitra </dt>
           <dd><em>maitr&#x00e1;</em> mf(<em>&#x012b;</em>)n. (fr. <em>mitra</em>, of, which it is also the V&#x1e5b;iddhi form in comp.) coming from or given by or belonging to a friend, friendly, amicable, benevolent, affectionate, kind <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Mn">Mn.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> &amp;c </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; a friend (= <em>mitra</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#P&#x0101;&#x1e47;">P&#x0101;&#x1e47;.</a> 5-4, 36 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#V&#x0101;rtt">V&#x0101;rtt.</a> 4 <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Pat">Pat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; N. of the 12th astrol. Yoga <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Col">Col.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; a man's N. much used as the N. of an imaginary person in giving examples in gram. and philos. (cf. <em>caitra</em> and Lat. <em>Caius</em>) </dd>

           <dt>moha </dt>
           <dd><em>m&#x00f3;ha</em> m. (&#x221a;1. <em>muh</em> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; ifc. f. <em>&#x0101;</em>) loss of consciousness, bewilderment, perplexity, distraction, infatuation, delusion, error, folly <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#AV">AV.</a> &amp;c. &amp;c. (<em>moham-&#x221a;br&#x016b;</em>, to say anything that leads to error </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>moha&#x1e43;-&#x221a;y&#x0101;</em>, to fall into error </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; <em>moh&#x0101;t</em> ind. through folly or ignorance) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; fainting, stupefaction, a swoon <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MBh">MBh.</a> <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#K&#x0101;v">K&#x0101;v.</a> &amp;c </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (in phil.) darkness or delusion of mind (preventing the discernment of truth and leading men to believe in the reality of worldly objects) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; (with Buddhists) ignorance (one of the three roots of vice <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Dharmas">Dharmas.</a> 139) </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; a magical art employed to bewilder an enemy (= <em>mohana</em>) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Cat">Cat.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; wonder, amazement <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#L">L.</a> </dd>
           <dd>&#x2022; Infatuation personified (as the offspring of Brahm&#x0101;) <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#VP">VP.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x22d9; mohakalila </dt>
           <dd><em>&#x25cb;kalila</em> n. thicket or snare of illusion <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#Bhag">Bhag.</a> </dd>

           <dd>&#x2022; charm, beauty <a href="worksAuthorsAbbrs.html#MW">MW.</a></dd>

           <dt>&#x226b; mrak&#x1e63;a </dt>
           <dd><em>mrak&#x1e63;a</em> mfn. rubbing, grinding down, destroying (cf. <em>tuvi-mr&#x25cb;</em>) </dd>
